channel.title: Using $_GET in form action
channel.description:
I am having some troubles with forms. I want it so that when clicking the form, it is handled by: "addcommenthandler.php?id=$_GET["id"]", for example, if $_GET["id"] was 2, clicking the form would take you to addcommenthandler.php?id=2.
Here is my code: [code]echo "<form action='addcommenthandler.php?id=".$_GET["id"]."' method='post'>[/code]
Yet it does not work - can anyone help?

@davidi2 wrote:

I may be misunderstanding what Taharok means, but if you only store post times in a session, and it expires when someone logs out, it seems to me like they could write a script where it posts, logs out, logs in again, and then posts again, loop, repeat. I guess it depends how well you design your log in as well, but that’s just an idea…

item.title: Using $_GET in form action
item.dc:creator: @mod_taharok Taharok
item.description:
@mod_taharok wrote:

[quote=“ranger squad, post:9, topic:426830”][quote author=Taharok link=topic=529528.msg3865136#msg3865136 date=1324944131]

The funny thing is, I did exactly the same thing about a minute before checking this thread Thankyou for the help, how would you recommend I make a system where they can only post one comment per minute?

You’ll have to record the time the last post occurred, preferably as part of the user’s session. If their session expires, they should be allowed to post again (unless you want long-term posting only, in which case you should consider persistent storage of the time, such as with a database).
[/quote]

What do you mean by “long-term posting”?[/quote]

I mean if you want the delay between posts to be greater than a typical session length (ie, a few hours to a day or more).

item.dc:creator: @_bool
item.description:
@_bool wrote:

you opened the string literal with a single quotes and attempted to close it with double quotes.

ps you can just do action=“addcommenthandler.php?id=$_GET[‘id’]” since iirc, php parses strings encapsulated in double quotes for variables and gives their value.
